review.title: Constrained Cohort Intelligence using Static and Dynamic Penalty Function Approach for Mechanical Components Design
review.abstract: Most of the metaheuristics can efficiently solve unconstrained problems; however, their performance may degenerate if the constraints are involved. This paper proposes two constraint handling approaches for an emerging metaheuristic of Cohort Intelligence (CI). More specifically CI with static penalty function approach (SCI) and CI with dynamic penalty function approach (DCI) are proposed. The approaches have been tested by solving several constrained test problems. The performance of the SCI and DCI have been compared with algorithms like GA, PSO, ABC, d-Ds. In addition, as well as three real world problems from mechanical engineering domain with improved solutions. The results were satisfactory and validated the applicability of CI methodology for solving real world problems.

sections.heading: 4.3. Thickening Problem in Tail Cap
sections.text: Thickening is one of the main faults of components produced by deep-drawing processes. It is necessary to minimize thickening in order to maintain the quality of the product. Determining the thickness distribution and thinning of the sheet metal cut reduces the production costs of the material and time. The ultimate goal of the deep-drawing process in particular, or of any sheet metal forming process in general, is to produce a good quality product, so uniform thickness should be achieved everywhere. Thickening minimization of the end cap in the deep-drawing process has been solved by SCI and DCI.

sections.heading: 4.3.1. Component Description
sections.text: The weight of the original component was 20 grams. The thickness of the chosen plate is 1.2. The material used is D 513, SS 4010. The yield strength of the material is 250

referenceMentions.context: The evolutionary algorithms include Genetic Algorithm (GA) (Mitchell 1996), Differential Evolution (DE) (Storn et al. 2013; Qin et al. 2009), etc.
So far, CI has been applied for solving several unconstrained test problems (Kulkarni et al. 2013).
Also, CI and modified CI (MCI) were hybridized with K-means (Krishnasamy et al. 2014) and applied for solving several data clustering problems.
The approach was also applied for solving traveling salesman problem (Kulkarni et al. 2017).
The performance of SCI & DCI is compared with the other methods in relevant literature including GA (Mezura-Montes and Coello 2005), PSO (Zavala et al.
